text: We propose a first principles account of the script construct that integrates its different uses in the behavioral and social sciences.

text: We begin by reviewing the recent literature that uses the script construct.

text: We then examine the main mathematical and computational features of active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Finally, we leverage the resources of active inference to offer a formal model of scripts.

text: There are some issues that stand in the way of an integrated model of scripts across fields.

text: In this paper, we focus on two orthogonal distinctions that we suggest structure discussion on scripts in the literature.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The first is a split between internalist and externalist readings of the construct of the script.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the internalist conception, a script is defined as a cognitive structure that is typically internal to an agent, e.g.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: encoded in their brain, and that harnesses information about typified behavioral patterns that are appropriate in specific social situations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the other, externalist conception, scripts are cast as the basic fabric from which social institutions are crafted.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On this conception, a script is a set of highly codified practices and rules
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: practices, norms, standards, beliefs, and linguistic practices and rules that make up an institution.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Some conceptions are not easy to split between internalist and externalist, but the way in which an agent interacts and reproduces a script does seem to bear elements of the duality nonetheless.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so that's where we return to these two extreme cases that were presented earlier, which is the ultimate internalist versus externalist.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The internal psychological schema is the internalist perspective, and it ultimately is going to tend towards neural reductionist perspectives.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The constitutive behavioral categories perspective is the externalist perspective, bigger systems, society influencing the individual, and that tends towards holism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These are the two tensions, the two poles of the script theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And just as we've seen before, we want to use active inference to reframe this variation along this axis from systems where it really does just plainly appear that it's a small thing that's bubbling up to cause a larger change,

text: or vice versa.

text: We want to take a new perspective on this question about the localization of scripts so that we can be better and act better in the world.

text: And the second dimension is a split between the weak and the strong readings of this term.

text: And the readings differ on how to explicitly think about the way that a script prescribes specific courses of action for the agents.

text: So in the strong concept of the script,
